title: Ticket #7260: LD_PRELOAD a fake getpwnam into sshd for condor_ssh_to_job
description:
LIGO (and the rest of the world) would really like condor_ssh_to_job to work with glided-in startds. There are several reasons these don't work today.

This ticket addresses one reason.

When the condor_startds spawns sshd, sshd runs as the non-root user of the job. At sshd startup, it looks at /etc/passwd to determine the shell and login name of the user. If this doesn't exist, or the shell isn't in /etc/shells, sshd will exit, and condor_ssh_to_job will unceremoniously hang up.

To fix this, we will LD_PRELOAD a fake getpwnam library call into sshd that returns a valid shell.

If this terrifies and administrator, a knob

CONDOR_SSH_TO_JOB_FAKE_PASSWD_ENTRY = false

will turn off the behavior.
remarks:
2019-Sep-16 13:05:39 by bbockelm:
This has a ring of "break security policy first, ask forgiveness later" -- which makes me fairly nervous.

I assume we want to have this turned off by default and make LIGO explicitly enable this, right? That way, they are explicitly accepting the risk of violating site security policy...

2019-Sep-17 07:54:46 by bbockelm:
In terms of code review:

  • Old-style C dec'l (static dirbuf[512];) causes the dirbuf to
  • The call to getcwd could fail and there is no error checking for getpwd. This includes buffer sizing issues -- this will fail if the pathname is 512 characters or longer.

2019-Sep-17 10:26:55 by bbockelm:
Chatting with Greg on Slack, the current version might run afoul of=seccomp= filtering in some versions of OpenSSH:

https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/sandbox-seccomp-filter.c

It appears that the getcwd syscall is not included in the list of permitted syscalls in that particular filter. Not sure if that is the filter in use by OpenSSH when getpwnam is called, however. Probably a good idea to avoid it though!

Could HTCondor put this information into an env var and allow us to avoid the syscall?
